keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after threats of violence were reported by his family.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle parked outside.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle has a prior conviction for marijuana possession over 20 years ago and is considered a convicted felon.
The incident occurred at one of the world’s busiest airports, which has over 108 million passengers annually and is the busiest in the world.
Cagle’s family alerted Cartersville police that he was armed and on his way to the airport, leading to coordination with Atlanta Police Department.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation due to the severity and potential for public harm.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens stated that Cagle had a semi-automatic weapon and was mentally challenged, which combined posed a deadly risk.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed gratitude that the individual was apprehended before causing harm.
The incident is described as a 'tragedy averted' by Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum, emphasizing the importance of public vigilance and reporting suspicious behavior.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family reported that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Although not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle, a convicted felon with a prior marijuana offense from over 20 years ago, faces multiple charges including terroristic threats and possession of a firearm. Authorities say he had arrived at the airport shortly before 9:30 a.m. and showed a strong interest in the TSA check-in area, which is heavily crowded. The incident, which occurred at the world’s busiest airport, was described as a 'tragedy averted' by Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum. The FBI is assisting in the investigation, and Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens highlighted the danger posed by combining a mental health condition with access to a semi-automatic weapon. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised law enforcement for preventing a potential tragedy. This event underscores the importance of public vigilance, inter-agency coordination, and airport security in high-traffic global hubs.
title: Man arrested inside Atlanta airport after making threats to ‘shoot it up’
